title: Plotting clustering trees
text: Clustering analysis used many contexts group similar samples. One problem conducting kind analysis many clusters use. usually controlled parameter provided clustering algorithm, \(k\) \(k\)-means clustering. Statistics designed help make choice typically either compare two clusterings score single clustering. clustering tree different visualises relationships range resolutions. build clustering tree need look cells move clustering resolution increased. cluster forms node tree edges constructed considering cells cluster lower resolution (say \(k = 2\)) end cluster next highest resolution (say \(k = 3\)). connecting clusters way can see clusters related , clearly distinct unstable. Extra information cells node can also overlaid order help make decision resolution use. information clustering trees please refer associated publication (Zappia Oshlack 2018).

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: demonstrate clustering tree looks like work short example using nba_clusts dataset.

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: nba_clusts dataset consists basic statistics 150 NBA players 2017, 50 three positions (Center, Point Guard Shooting Guards). dataset clustered using \(k\)-means different values \(k\). information see ?nba_clusts. Let’s load data take look: data.frame player positions statistics (turnover percentage, rebound percentage, assist percentage field goal percentage) well additional columns. columns contain cluster assignments clustering data using \(k\)-means values \(k\) \(k = 1\) \(k = 5\).

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: clustering information need build clustering tree. column must consist numeric values indicating cluster sample assigned . plot tree just pass information clustree function. also need specify prefix string indicate columns contain clusterings.  can see one cluster distinct change value \(k\). Center players different positions. side tree see single cluster splits two clusters expect see. tree becomes messier node multiple incoming edges. good indication clustered data.
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: default size node related number samples cluster colour indicates clustering resolution. Edges coloured according number samples represent transparency shows incoming node proportion, number samples edge divided number samples node points . can control aesthetics setting specific values:  can also link aesthetics information samples. additional columns dataset available added attributes nodes tree. node represents multiple samples need supply aggregation function use well specifying column name. Let’s try colouring nodes according rebound percentage:  can clearly see distinct cluster containing Center players higher rebound percentage average compared clusters.
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", node_colour = "purple", node_size = 10,          node_alpha = 0.8) clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", node_colour = "ReboundPct",          node_colour_aggr = "mean")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: Apart information dataset can useful display measures clustering quality aesthetics. stability index {SC3} package (Kiselev et al. 2017) measures stability clusters across resolutions automatically calculated clustering tree built. can accessed setting aesthetic "sc3_stability" calculated cluster don’t need provide aggregation function. example:
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", node_colour = "sc3_stability")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: default tree drawn using Reingold-Tilford tree layout algorithm tries place nodes parents (Reingold Tilford 1981). Alternatively use Sugiyama layout specifying layout argument. algorithm tries minimise number crossing edges (Sugiyama, Tagawa, Toda 1981) can produce attractive trees cases.  layout algorithms clustree() uses slightly modified versions tree default. core network edges, highest -proportion edge node, used creating layout. cases leads attractive trees easier interpret. turn , use edges deciding layout, can set use_core_edges FALSE.
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", layout = "sugiyama") clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", layout = "sugiyama", use_core_edges = FALSE)

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: make easy identify clusters cluster nodes labelled cluster number (controlled using node_text arguments) sometimes useful add labels additional information. done way aesthetics. label nodes maximum assist percentage:  One way can useful assigned labels samples. custom function labels cluster players position, otherwise labels cluster “mixed”:
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", node_label = "AssistPct",          node_label_aggr = "max") label_position <- function(labels) {     if (length(unique(labels)) == 1) {         position <- as.character(unique(labels))     } else {         position <- "mixed"     }     return(position) }  clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", node_label = "Position",          node_label_aggr = "label_position")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: Clustering become core tool analysing single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) datasets. datasets contain gene expression measurements hundreds hundreds thousands cells. Often samples come complex tissues containing many types cells clustering used group similar cells together. make easier produce clustering trees kinds datasets provide interfaces objects commonly used analyse scRNA-seq data. clustree package contains example simulated scRNA-seq data clustered using {SC3} {Seurat} (Satija et al. 2015) packages.
code: data("sc_example") names(sc_example) #> [1] "counts"          "logcounts"       "tsne"            "sc3_clusters"    #> [5] "seurat_clusters"

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: SingleCellExperiment one common objects, used across range Bioconductor packages. Let’s look example, first need convert example dataset SingleCellExperiment object: clustering information held coldata slot. can plot clustering tree way data.frame. case clustering column names contain suffix needs stripped away, pass along well.
code: #> Warning: replacing previous import 'S4Arrays::makeNindexFromArrayViewport' by #> 'DelayedArray::makeNindexFromArrayViewport' when loading 'SummarizedExperiment' suppressPackageStartupMessages(library("SingleCellExperiment"))  sce <- SingleCellExperiment(assays = list(counts = sc_example$counts,                                           logcounts = sc_example$logcounts),                             colData = sc_example$sc3_clusters,                             reducedDims = SimpleList(TSNE = sc_example$tsne)) head(colData(sce)) #> DataFrame with 6 rows and 8 columns #>       sc3_1_clusters sc3_2_clusters sc3_3_clusters sc3_4_clusters #>             <factor>       <factor>       <factor>       <factor> #> Cell1              1              2              3              4 #> Cell2              1              2              3              2 #> Cell3              1              1              1              1 #> Cell4              1              1              1              3 #> Cell5              1              2              3              4 #> Cell6              1              2              2              2 #>       sc3_5_clusters sc3_6_clusters sc3_7_clusters sc3_8_clusters #>             <factor>       <factor>       <factor>       <factor> #> Cell1              3              2              2              3 #> Cell2              2              1              1              1 #> Cell3              5              4              4              5 #> Cell4              4              3              3              4 #> Cell5              3              2              5              8 #> Cell6              2              1              1              1 clustree(sce, prefix = "sc3_", suffix = "_clusters")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: NOTE: section requires Seurat package (>= 5.0.0). package isn’t installed results won’t shown. Clustering trees can also produced directly Seurat objects. Let’s convert SingleCellExperiment Seurat format: case clustering information held meta.data slot can accessed using [[ operator: can now produce clustering tree using object. example prefix clustering columns res. cases default prefix Seurat automatically used. Note: example uses newer Seurat object available version 3.0.0 greater Seurat. also interface older seurat object may deprecated future.
code: suppressPackageStartupMessages(library("Seurat"))  # Create the Seurat object, Seurat >= expects a sparse matrix seurat <- CreateSeuratObject(counts = as(sc_example$counts, "sparseMatrix"),                              data = as(sc_example$logcounts, "sparseMatrix"),                              meta.data = sc_example$seurat_clusters)  # Add the t-SNE embedding seurat[['TSNE']] <- CreateDimReducObject(embeddings = sc_example$tsne,                                          key = "tSNE_") head(seurat[[]]) clustree(seurat, prefix = "res.")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: well able use additional columns aesthetics can also use expression individual genes. Let’s colour nodes Seurat tree Gene730 (highly variable gene). need supply aggregation function.
code: clustree(seurat, prefix = "res.",          node_colour = "Gene730", node_colour_aggr = "median")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: One way think clustering trees add extra dimension data shows clusters “evolve” time (increasing resolution). times can useful overlay dimension dimensions data, particularly come dimensionality reduction techniques. can using clustree_overlay function:  easiest way understand plot imagine looking clustering tree . x y axes chosen dimensions data z axis clustering resolution. cluster node placed mean x y values samples contains. can also see points corresponding individual samples.
code: clustree_overlay(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", x_value = "PC1", y_value = "PC2")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: Due way ggplot2 works can colour one element plot (node points actually use fill aesthetic). default tree edges coloured according clustering resolution originate . Alternatively can choose colour sample points highest resolution cluster. colour whichever element isn’t using colour aesthetic can set using alt_colour argument.  Aesthetics clustering tree nodes can controlled way regular clustree function additional arguments adjusting appearance edges points.
code: clustree_overlay(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", x_value = "PC1", y_value = "PC2",                  use_colour = "points", alt_colour = "blue")

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: One downsides visualisation can hard identify clusters node represents can often overlap. make bit easier can label node resolution cluster ID.
code: clustree_overlay(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", x_value = "PC1", y_value = "PC2",                  label_nodes = TRUE)

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: main overlay plot show us tree can also useful see side, showing one x y dimensions resolution dimension. can get views setting plot_sides option TRUE. return list ggplot objects instead single plot.
code: overlay_list <- clustree_overlay(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", x_value = "PC1",                                  y_value = "PC2", plot_sides = TRUE)  names(overlay_list) #> [1] "overlay" "x_side"  "y_side"  overlay_list$x_side overlay_list$y_side

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: clustree() function returns ggplot object can modified using functions {ggplot2} {ggraph} packages. example change colour scales used nodes edges:
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K") +     scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +     scale_edge_color_continuous(low = "blue", high = "red") #> Scale for edge_colour is already present. #> Adding another scale for edge_colour, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Plotting clustering trees
text: way ggplot objects displayed relative size plotting window output file. main plot always fit sometimes legends placed outside visible area. One solution simply increase size image. alternative solution turn legends, either setting aesthetics static values using guides function. also move somewhere might fit better. example let’s remove edge legends move rest bottom:
code: clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K") +     guides(edge_colour = FALSE, edge_alpha = FALSE) +     theme(legend.position = "bottom") #> Warning: The `<scale>` argument of `guides()` cannot be `FALSE`. Use "none" instead as #> of ggplot2 3.3.4. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated.

title: Visualise Clusterings at Different Resolutions
text: can install release version clustree CRAN : want use development version can installed GitHub using remotes package: also build vignettes use: NOTE: Building vignettes requires installation additional packages.
code: install.packages("clustree") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("lazappi/clustree@develop") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("lazappi/clustree@develop", dependencies = TRUE,                          build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: Calculate SC3 stability — calc_sc3_stability
text: Calculate SC3 stability index every cluster every resolution set clusterings. index varies 0 1, 1 suggests cluster stable across resolutions. See calc_sc3_stability_cluster() details.

title: Calculate single SC3 stability — calc_sc3_stability_cluster
text: clusterings numeric matrix containing clustering information, column contains clustering separate resolution res resolution cluster calculate stability cluster index cluster calculate stability

title: Calculate single SC3 stability — calc_sc3_stability_cluster
text: SC3 stability index

title: Calculate single SC3 stability — calc_sc3_stability_cluster
text: index originally introduced SC3 package clustering single-cell RNA-seq data. Clusters awarded increased stability share samples cluster another resolution penalised higher resolutions. use slightly different notation describe score results : $$   s(c_{k, }) =   \frac{1}{size(L) + 1}   \sum_{l \L}     \sum_{j \N_l}       \frac{size(c_{k, } \cap c_{l, j})}{size(c_{l, j}) * size(N_l) ^ 2} $$ : c_{x, y} cluster y resolution x k resolution cluster want score index cluster want score L set resolutions except k l resolution L N_l set clusters resolution l share samples c_{k, } j cluster N_l

title: Clustree — clustree-package

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
text: Creates plot clustering tree showing relationship clusterings different resolutions.

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
code: clustree(x, ...)  # S3 method for matrix clustree(   x,   prefix,   suffix = NULL,   metadata = NULL,   count_filter = 0,   prop_filter = 0.1,   layout = c("tree", "sugiyama"),   use_core_edges = TRUE,   highlight_core = FALSE,   node_colour = prefix,   node_colour_aggr = NULL,   node_size = "size",   node_size_aggr = NULL,   node_size_range = c(4, 15),   node_alpha = 1,   node_alpha_aggr = NULL,   node_text_size = 3,   scale_node_text = FALSE,   node_text_colour = "black",   node_text_angle = 0,   node_label = NULL,   node_label_aggr = NULL,   node_label_size = 3,   node_label_nudge = -0.2,   edge_width = 1.5,   edge_arrow = TRUE,   edge_arrow_ends = c("last", "first", "both"),   show_axis = FALSE,   return = c("plot", "graph", "layout"),   ... )  # S3 method for data.frame clustree(x, prefix, ...)  # S3 method for SingleCellExperiment clustree(x, prefix, exprs = "counts", ...)  # S3 method for seurat clustree(x, prefix = "res.", exprs = c("data", "raw.data", "scale.data"), ...)  # S3 method for Seurat clustree(   x,   prefix = paste0(assay, "_snn_res."),   exprs = c("data", "counts", "scale.data"),   assay = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
text: x object containing clustering data ... extra parameters passed methods prefix string indicating columns containing clustering information suffix string end column names containing clustering information metadata data.frame containing metadata sample can used node aesthetics count_filter count threshold filtering edges clustering graph prop_filter proportion threshold filtering edges clustering graph layout string specifying "tree" "sugiyama" layout, see igraph::layout_as_tree() igraph::layout_with_sugiyama() details use_core_edges logical, whether use core tree (edges maximum proportion node) creating graph layout, (unfiltered) edges still displayed highlight_core logical, whether increase edge width core network make easier see node_colour either value indicating colour use nodes name metadata column colour nodes node_colour_aggr node_colour column name string giving name function aggregate column samples cluster node_size either numeric value giving size nodes name metadata column use node sizes node_size_aggr node_size column name string giving name function aggregate column samples cluster node_size_range numeric vector length two giving maximum minimum point size plotting nodes node_alpha either numeric value giving alpha nodes name metadata column use node transparency node_alpha_aggr node_aggr column name string giving name function aggregate column samples cluster node_text_size numeric value giving size node text scale_node_text FALSE scale_node_text logical indicating whether scale node text along node size node_text_colour colour value node text (label) node_text_angle rotation node text node_label additional label add nodes node_label_aggr node_label column name string giving name function aggregate column samples cluster node_label_size numeric value giving size node label text node_label_nudge numeric value giving nudge y direction node labels edge_width numeric value giving width plotted edges edge_arrow logical indicating whether add arrow edges edge_arrow_ends string indicating ends line draw arrow heads edge_arrow TRUE, one "last", "first", "" show_axis whether show resolution axis return string specifying return, either "plot" (ggplot object), "graph" (tbl_graph object) "layout" (ggraph layout object) exprs source gene expression information use node aesthetics, SingleCellExperiment objects must name assayNames(x), seurat object must one data, raw.data scale.data Seurat object must one data, counts scale.data assay name assay pull expression clustering data Seurat objects

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
text: ggplot object (default), tbl_graph object ggraph layout object depending value return

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
text: Data sources Plotting clustering tree requires information cluster sample assigned different resolutions. information can supplied various forms, matrix, data.frame specialised object. cases object provided must contain numeric columns naming structure PXS P prefix indicating column contains clustering information, X numeric value indicating clustering resolution S additional suffix removed. SingleCellExperiment objects information must colData slot Seurat objects must meta.data slot. objects except matrices additional columns can used aesthetics, matrices additional metadata data.frame can supplied required. Filtering Edges graph can filtered adjusting count_filter prop_filter parameters. count_filter removes edges represent less number samples, prop_filter removes edges represent less proportion cells node points towards. Node aesthetics aesthetics plotted nodes can controlled various ways. default colour indicates clustering resolution, size indicates number samples cluster transparency set 100%. can set specific value linked supplied metadata column. SingleCellExperiment Seurat object names genes can also used. metadata column used aggregation function must also supplied combine samples cluster. function must take vector values return single value. Layout clustering tree can displayed using either Reingold-Tilford tree layout algorithm Sugiyama layout algorithm layered directed acyclic graphs. layouts selected algorithms available igraph package designed trees. Reingold-Tilford algorithm places children parents Sugiyama places nodes layers trying minimise number crossing edges. See igraph::layout_as_tree() igraph::layout_with_sugiyama() details. use_core_edges TRUE (default) core tree maximum proportion edges node used constructing layout. can often lead attractive layouts core tree visible.

title: Plot a clustering tree — clustree
code: data(nba_clusts) clustree(nba_clusts, prefix = "K")

title: Overlay a clustering tree — clustree_overlay
text: Creates plot clustering tree overlaid scatter plot individual samples.

title: Overlay a clustering tree — clustree_overlay
code: clustree_overlay(x, ...)  # S3 method for matrix clustree_overlay(   x,   prefix,   metadata,   x_value,   y_value,   suffix = NULL,   count_filter = 0,   prop_filter = 0.1,   node_colour = prefix,   node_colour_aggr = NULL,   node_size = "size",   node_size_aggr = NULL,   node_size_range = c(4, 15),   node_alpha = 1,   node_alpha_aggr = NULL,   edge_width = 1,   use_colour = c("edges", "points"),   alt_colour = "black",   point_size = 3,   point_alpha = 0.2,   point_shape = 18,   label_nodes = FALSE,   label_size = 3,   plot_sides = FALSE,   side_point_jitter = 0.45,   side_point_offset = 1,   ... )  # S3 method for data.frame clustree_overlay(x, prefix, ...)  # S3 method for SingleCellExperiment clustree_overlay(   x,   prefix,   x_value,   y_value,   exprs = "counts",   red_dim = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for seurat clustree_overlay(   x,   x_value,   y_value,   prefix = "res.",   exprs = c("data", "raw.data", "scale.data"),   red_dim = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for Seurat clustree_overlay(   x,   x_value,   y_value,   prefix = paste0(assay, "_snn_res."),   exprs = c("data", "counts", "scale.data"),   red_dim = NULL,   assay = NULL,   ... )

text: ggplot object plot_sides FALSE list ggplot objects plot_sides TRUE

title: Overlay a clustering tree — clustree_overlay
text: Data sources Plotting clustering tree requires information cluster sample assigned different resolutions. information can supplied various forms, matrix, data.frame specialised object. cases object provided must contain numeric columns naming structure PXS P prefix indicating column contains clustering information, X numeric value indicating clustering resolution S additional suffix removed. SingleCellExperiment objects information must colData slot Seurat objects must meta.data slot. objects except matrices additional columns can used aesthetics. Filtering Edges graph can filtered adjusting count_filter prop_filter parameters. count_filter removes edges represent less number samples, prop_filter removes edges represent less proportion cells node points towards. Node aesthetics aesthetics plotted nodes can controlled various ways. default colour indicates clustering resolution, size indicates number samples cluster transparency set 100%. can set specific value linked supplied metadata column. SingleCellExperiment Seurat object names genes can also used. metadata column used aggregation function must also supplied combine samples cluster. function must take vector values return single value. Colour aesthetic colour aesthetic can applied either edges sample points setting use_colour. "edges" selected edges coloured according clustering resolution originate . "points" selected coloured according cluster assigned highest resolution. Dimensionality reductions SingleCellExperiment Seurat objects precomputed dimensionality reductions can used x y aesthetics. red_dim must set name dimensionality reduction reducedDimNames(x) (SingleCellExperiment) x@dr (Seurat object). x_value y_value can set red_dimX red_dim matches red_dim argument X column dimensionality reduction use.

title: Overlay a clustering tree — clustree_overlay
code: data(nba_clusts) clustree_overlay(nba_clusts, prefix = "K", x_value = "PC1", y_value = "PC2")

title: Clustered NBA positions dataset — nba_clusts
text: nba_clusts data.frame containing NBA positions dataset additional columns holding k-means clusterings different values k first two principal components Position - Player position TurnoverPct - Turnover percentage ReboundPct - Rebound percentage AssistPct - Assist percentage FieldGoalPct - Field goal percentage K1 - K5 - Results k-means clustering PC1 - First principal component PC2 - Second principal component

title: Clustered NBA positions dataset — nba_clusts
text: NBA positions downloaded https://github.com/lazappi/nba_positions. source dataset available Kaggle https://www.kaggle.com/drgilermo/nba-players-stats/data?select=Seasons_Stats.csv originally scraped Basketball Reference. See https://github.com/lazappi/clustree/blob/master/data-raw/nba_clusts.R details clustering performed.

text: nodes data.frame describing nodes x_value column nodes use x position y_value column nodes use y position node_colour either value indicating colour use nodes name metadata column colour nodes node_size either numeric value giving size nodes name metadata column use node sizes node_alpha either numeric value giving alpha nodes name metadata column use node transparency

title: Plot overlay side — plot_overlay_side
text: Plot side view clustree overlay plot. ordinary plot shows tree plot shows side, highlighting either x y dimension clustering resolution.

title: Plot overlay side — plot_overlay_side
code: plot_overlay_side(   nodes,   edges,   points,   prefix,   side_value,   graph_attr,   node_size_range,   edge_width,   use_colour,   alt_colour,   point_size,   point_alpha,   point_shape,   label_nodes,   label_size,   y_jitter,   y_offset )

title: Plot overlay side — plot_overlay_side
text: nodes data.frame describing nodes edges data.frame describing edges points data.frame describing points prefix string indicating columns containing clustering information side_value string giving metadata column use x axis graph_attr list describing graph attributes node_size_range numeric vector length two giving maximum minimum point size plotting nodes edge_width numeric value giving width plotted edges use_colour one "edges" "points" specifying element apply colour aesthetic alt_colour colour value used edges points (whichever given use_colour) point_size numeric value giving size sample points point_alpha numeric value giving alpha sample points point_shape numeric value giving shape sample points label_nodes logical value indicating whether add labels clustering graph nodes label_size numeric value giving size node labels label_nodes TRUE y_jitter numeric value giving y-direction spread points side plots y_offset numeric value giving y-direction offset points side plots

title: Plot overlay side — plot_overlay_side
text: ggplot object

title: Simulated scRNA-seq dataset — sc_example
text: simulated scRNA-seq dataset generated using splatter package clustered using SC3 Seurat packages.

title: Simulated scRNA-seq dataset — sc_example
code: sc_example

title: Simulated scRNA-seq dataset — sc_example
text: sc_example list holding simulated scRNA-seq dataset. Items list included simulated counts, normalised log counts, tSNE dimensionality reduction cell assignments SC3 Seurat clustering.

title: Simulated scRNA-seq dataset — sc_example
code: # Simulation library("splatter") # Version 1.2.1  sim <- splatSimulate(batchCells = 200, nGenes = 10000,                      group.prob = c(0.4, 0.2, 0.2, 0.15, 0.05),                      de.prob = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.05, 0.1, 0.05),                      method = "groups", seed = 1) sim_counts <- counts(sim)[1:1000, ]  # SC3 Clustering library("SC3") # Version 1.7.6 library("scater") # Version 1.6.2  sim_sc3 <- SingleCellExperiment(assays = list(counts = sim_counts)) rowData(sim_sc3)$feature_symbol <- rownames(sim_counts) sim_sc3 <- normalise(sim_sc3) sim_sc3 <- sc3(sim_sc3, ks = 1:8, biology = FALSE, n_cores = 1) sim_sc3 <- runTSNE(sim_sc3)  # Seurat Clustering library("Seurat") # Version 2.2.0  sim_seurat <- CreateSeuratObject(sim_counts) sim_seurat <- NormalizeData(sim_seurat, display.progress = FALSE) sim_seurat <- FindVariableGenes(sim_seurat, do.plot = FALSE,                                 display.progress = FALSE) sim_seurat <- ScaleData(sim_seurat, display.progress = FALSE) sim_seurat <- RunPCA(sim_seurat, do.print = FALSE) sim_seurat <- FindClusters(sim_seurat, dims.use = 1:6,                            resolution = seq(0, 1, 0.1),                            print.output = FALSE)  sc_example <- list(counts = counts(sim_sc3),                    logcounts = logcounts(sim_sc3),                    tsne = reducedDim(sim_sc3),                    sc3_clusters = as.data.frame(colData(sim_sc3)),                    seurat_clusters = sim_seurat@meta.data)
